Award.AwardTitle: NSF NPGI Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2014
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF National Plant Genome Initiative Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2014. The fellowship supports a research and training plan in a host laboratory for the Fellow who also presents a plan to broaden participation in biology. The title of the research and training plan for this fellowship to Matthew Zinkgraf is "Transcriptional Regulation and Gene Networks Underlying Vascular Cambium Development in Populus". The host institutions for the fellowship are the US Forest Service and the University of California, Davis and the sponsoring scientists are Drs. Andrew Groover and Vladimir Filkov.

The research will lead to a more fundamental understanding of secondary, woody growth in trees. Secondary growth is an important part of the carbon cycle, specifically carbon sequestration, and an integral aspect of forest ecology. The training objectives of this project include learning opportunities in advanced molecular genetic techniques and computational biology for the Fellow and the development of an independent career. Broader impacts include mentoring undergraduate students, professional development, and public outreach to communities in California and Wisconsin.

The proposed research focuses on secondary growth, the radial growth of woody tree stems from the vascular cambium meristem. Secondary growth presents opportunities to understand fundamental aspects of tree growth that are of direct economic and environmental importance. This project will use genomic tools to characterize transcription factors that regulate gene expression during secondary growth in the model forest tree, Populus. This will allow for the use advanced computational methods to examine fundamental features of transcriptional regulation during secondary growth, including the role of combinatorial binding of transcription factors in regulating gene expression, and the topology of transcriptional networks. The outcomes of the research will lead to a fuller understanding of the genes and gene networks involved in secondary growth in trees, important to carbon cycling and ecology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Angiosperm trees grow in a diverse array of habitats, and must integrate environmental and developmental signals during the formation of woody tissues. For example, woody stems perceive gravity to determine their orientation and manipulate wood developmental pathways to produce tension wood, which is characterized by specialized fibers that create tensile force to pull stems upright. Increasing evidence suggests that these signals are integrated through complex networks and regulatory interactions. Understanding the biological regulation of woody growth in trees is ecologically and economically relevant because forests contain over 80% of terrestrial biomass and represent approximately three percent of the total world trade.

A detailed understanding of the regulatory processes involved in the formation of wood tissues in forest trees has been lacking but these results will be instrumental in the development of domesticated Populus and closely related Salix genotypes with desirable wood characteristics. Much of the previous work on the regulation of wood development has focused on a limited number of genes or specific regulatory interactions in Arabidopsis and a handful of woody species. These approaches have been beneficial in providing a starting point to understand wood development in tree species, but lack the power to comprehensively describe the interactions among complex pathways underlying wood formation, which involve thousands of genes.

The goal of this project was to apply advanced genomic and computational approaches to understand regulatory processes for wood formation in an undomesticated tree species. This research will: (1) aid in the basic discovery and characterization of the genes involved in the formation of woody tissues; (2) integrate large-scale genomic datasets to address the effects of combinatorial transcription factor binding on gene expression; (3) provide one of the first studies to model transcriptional regulatory networks in undomesticated trees; (4) provide me with new training opportunities to meet my career goals.

The work by Dr. Zinkgraf and colleagues utilized several large-scale genomics studies primarily focused in Populus to understand transcriptional regulation at multiple levels. First, at the level of individual genes, the regulatory targets of five key transcription factors were identified for developing xylem using genome-wide transcription factor binding experiments. Second, we modeled temporal and tissue specific changes in gene expression across the genome underlying wood formation using gravi-stimulation experiments and tension wood responses. Gravi-stimulation is a controlled manipulation that stimulates a developmental shift in wood development pathways and mimics the natural gravitropic response in angiosperm trees. Third, we integrated the results from the previous experiments and have found that integration of diverse genome-wide data sets directly in a tree species can be used to identify and describe core regulatory pathways that have functional relevance to wood formation. These include how transcription factors bind onto the DNA to influence gene expression in woody stems, how hormone signaling impacts wood development, and how trees integrate environmental signals into complex developmental pathways to produce wood tissues that are adaptive for environmental conditions. Lastly, the extensive results from Populus were extended to other woody species to investigate the genetics of wood formation and generate genomic resources in less studied angiosperm and monocot species. For example, Dr. Zinkgraf and colleagues developed a comparative genomics approach to understand the evolution of gravitropic responses across multiple species of angiosperm trees from the genera Liriodendron, Liquidambar, Eucalyptus, Populus and Salix. This approach will be used to determine how transcriptional networks associated with wood formation have evolved across angiosperm trees and identify both the ancestral set of core regulatory genes that play similar roles in all species, as well as genes unique to phylogenetic lineages or individual species.               

During the fellowship, Dr. Zinkgraf disseminated the results from this research project to the scientific community by publishing five peer-reviewed manuscripts and there are two additional papers in preparation. In addition, major research talks were presented at six conferences, including the Plant and Animal Genome Conference and in international meeting on forest tree genomics at Harvard’s Arnold Arboretum.

As part of his professional development and to broaden participation in science, Dr. Zinkgraf mentored several graduate students, and created an eight-week course on bioinformatics. This course focused on computational skill development and analytical approaches to working with genomic datasets. Because of the popularity, this course was presented in person three times to a diverse group of undergrads, postdocs and technicians in Davis CA, and through video conferencing across Pacific Southwest Research Station. In addition, an abbreviated version of this course was taught to approximately 15 undergraduate and graduate students at the Chinese Academy of Forestry in Beijing, China.
